top_categories.workout_context: Rasputitsa’s vermont class 4 roads (unmaintained dirt), mud (guaranteed in april) demands rapid power changes — surge over obstacles, settle on smoother sections, repeat for hours.
Racing Rasputitsa isn’t just fitness — it’s pacing, fueling, and executing when conditions deteriorate. This workout practices the race itself.
Rasputitsa’s vermont class 4 roads—unmaintained dirt, mud drains energy reserves faster than the distance suggests — durability training bridges the gap.
Critical power determines how long you can sustain above-threshold efforts at Rasputitsa — a higher CP means more time in the red before failure.
Over-unders train the lactate clearance you’ll need at Rasputitsa when surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding hard.
Rasputitsa’s vermont class 4 roads—unmaintained dirt, mud and competitive field demand explosive aerobic capacity — the ability to respond to surges without blowing up.
Rasputitsa rewards athletes who can hold sustained power without blowing up — threshold is the engine that drives everything above Zone 2.
Short, violent efforts are unavoidable at Rasputitsa — climbs demanding 2-minute maximal efforts, surges to close gaps, attacks on vermont class 4 roads—unmaintained dirt, mud.
Rasputitsa’s 5,000ft of climbing demands seated and standing versatility — the ability to change climbing style as gradient and fatigue dictate.
Every session at Rasputitsa intensity builds on this aerobic foundation — the endurance base is the soil everything else grows in.
Cadence efficiency makes every pedal stroke at Rasputitsa count — smooth technique reduces muscular fatigue over long distances.
The G-Spot zone (88–92% FTP) is where you’ll spend the hardest sustained miles of Rasputitsa. Make this intensity feel like home.

race_overlay.heat: April in Burke, Vermont — 35-55°F, 40% rain chance, mud guaranteed. 'Rasputitsa' = Russian for 'mud season'. Begin heat acclimatization 10–14 days before Rasputitsa — 20–30min sauna sessions or midday rides in full kit. Pre-load sodium 48 hours out. Target 500–750ml/hr with electrolytes on race day.
race_overlay.nutrition: Target 40–60g carbs/hour for Rasputitsa’s 46 miles. Front-load calories in the first half. One bottle per hour minimum, more in heat.
race_overlay.terrain: Highly technical terrain at Rasputitsa demands practice on similar surfaces. Ride vermont class 4 roads—unmaintained dirt, mud at race-day cadence weekly. Expect: vermont class 4 roads (unmaintained dirt), mud (guaranteed in april), technical climbs. Practice cornering, descending, and power delivery on unstable surfaces. Dial in tire pressure before race week — 5 PSI wrong costs you 15+ minutes over 46 miles.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Gravel Specific, Race Simulation, and Durability to prepare you for 46 miles of vermont class 4 roads—unmaintained dirt, mud in Burke, Vermont.
